intro: Buchnera ciliolata, commonly known as the silky broomrape, is a parasitic plant that lacks chlorophyll and relies on host plants for nutrients. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and is characterized by its smooth, hairless stems and small, inconspicuous flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats and is often found in association with grasses and other herbaceous plants. Its unique botanical features make it an interesting subject for studies on parasitic plant biology. Buchnera ciliolata is also noted for its ability to produce a sticky substance that may aid in seed dispersal.
